Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I could see the worry lines deepening on my husband’s face as he sat at the kitchen table, his hands wrapped around a mug he hadn’t touched. He needed me—needed my words, my arms, my undivided attention. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: Mrs. Lee’s appointment in fifteen minutes. At the salon, Mrs. Lee was already in the chair, smiling as she asked if I could trim her fringe just a bit more. She was always so understanding, but I knew how much she valued these little details. My mind kept drifting back to my husband, picturing him alone, waiting for comfort I wasn’t there to give. I tried to focus on Mrs. Lee, to listen and reassure her, but my heart was split. I felt the weight of both their needs pressing on me, each expecting my full presence, each deserving it. My hands trembled slightly as I picked up the scissors, torn between the woman in my chair and the man at home, both looking to me for something only I could give.
